content.question:
For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.  

Answer the following questions about weak acids. Use the <math alttext="K sub a"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> values in the following table to help answer some of the questions.
Acid<math alttext="K sub a"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="H F"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="6.7 times 10 to the negative 4 "><mstyle><mrow><mn>6.7</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="H C 2 H 3 O 2"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>HC</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="1.8 times 10 to the negative 5 "><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.8</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>
(a) Using the expression <math alttext="K sub a equals the fraction with numerator the molar concentration of H with a positive 1 charge, times the molar concentration of A with a negative 1 charge, and denominator the molar concentration of H A"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mtext>[</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>][</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>]</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>[</mtext><mtext>HA</mtext><mtext>]</mtext></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>, explain how to determine which solution has the lower <math alttext="p H"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="0.10 molar H F aqueous"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.10</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>HF</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> or <math alttext="0.10 molar H C 2 H 3 O 2 aqueous"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.10</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>HC</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Do not perform any numerical calculations.

frqParts.text:
For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.  

Answer the following questions about weak acids. Use the <math alttext="K sub a"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> values in the following table to help answer some of the questions.
Acid<math alttext="K sub a"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="H F"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="6.7 times 10 to the negative 4 "><mstyle><mrow><mn>6.7</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="H C 2 H 3 O 2"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>HC</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="1.8 times 10 to the negative 5 "><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.8</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>
(a) Using the expression <math alttext="K sub a equals the fraction with numerator the molar concentration of H with a positive 1 charge, times the molar concentration of A with a negative 1 charge, and denominator the molar concentration of H A"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mtext>[</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>][</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>]</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>[</mtext><mtext>HA</mtext><mtext>]</mtext></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>, explain how to determine which solution has the lower <math alttext="p H"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="0.10 molar H F aqueous"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.10</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>HF</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> or <math alttext="0.10 molar H C 2 H 3 O 2 aqueous"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.10</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>HC</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Do not perform any numerical calculations.

(b) Which solution has a higher percent ionization of the acid, a <math alttext="0.10 molar"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.10</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> solution of <math alttext="H C 2 H 3 O 2 aqueous"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>HC</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> or a <math alttext="0.010 molar "><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.010</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> solution of <math alttext="H C 2 H 3 O 2 aqueous "><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>HC</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Justify your answer including the calculation of percent ionization for each solution.

(c) A student titrated <math alttext="50.0 milliliters " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of a <math alttext="0.10 molar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.10</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> solution of a certain weak acid with <math alttext="N a O H aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaOH</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>. The results are given in the graph above.

(i) What is the approximate <math alttext="p K sub a" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>p</mtext><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> of the acid?

(ii) What specific value from the graph is needed, in addition to the information in part <math alttext="c" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>(c)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> above, to calculate the molar concentration of the <math alttext="N a O H aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaOH</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>?

(iii) Identify a <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> value between 2.5 and 7.5 at which the concentration of the weak acid being titrated is less than the concentration of its conjugate base.

(d) In another experiment, the student titrated <math alttext="50.0 milliliters "><mstyle><mrow><mn>50.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="0.100 molar H C 2 H 3 O 2"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.100</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>HC</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> with <math alttext="0.100 molar N a O H aqueous"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.100</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>NaOH</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>. Calculate the <math alttext="p H"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of the solution at the equivalence point.

skill.text: 2.D: Make observations or collect data from representations of laboratory setups or results, while attending to precision where appropriate.
